timeline.bodyText: @franz1981 can we please not use wildcard imports :) ?
timeline.author: normanmaurer

timeline.message:
Reduce garbage on MQTT encoding

Motivation:

MqttEncoder create many byte[] to encode Strings into UTF-8 bytes

Modification:

ByteBufUtil::utf8Bytes and ByteBufUtil::reserveAndWriteUtf8 allows to perform the same operation GC-free

Result:
Less garbage produced on Mqtt encoding

Reduce garbage on MQTT encoding

Modification:

Result:
Less garbage produced on Mqtt encoding

Reduce garbage on MQTT encoding

timeline.bodyText: I prefer to move the array allocations to the static block, so you don't have to hard code the array length like this. Same in MqttQoS.
timeline.author: chrisvest

timeline.message:
Reduce garbage on MQTT encoding/decoding

Motivation:

Some enums valueOf create unnecessary arrays on the hot paths

Modification:

Implemented GC free const table lookup/switch valueOf

Result:
Less garbage produced on Mqtt

timeline.bodyText: I don't think these changes to set max capacity == init capacity should be necessary, it won't affect how the buffer is allocated just the cap on how large it can grow beyond init capacity (which it won't because it's being sized precisely up-front IIUC).
timeline.author: njhill

timeline.bodyText: Above lines could be moved inside the if block I think? (I know not strictly related to this PR)
timeline.author: njhill
njhill

timeline.bodyText: This isn't necessary.. buf will be expanded inside reserveAndWriteUtf8 if needed
timeline.author: njhill

replies.bodyText:
I would like the whole required writable capacity to be already allocated and the assert should just check it.
In the current implementation writeUTF8String is using buf.ensureWritable(buf.capacity() - writerIndex); explicitly instead of relying on reserveAndWriteUtf8 because:

there are 0-length strings that still need buf.setShort(writerIndex, utf8Length); with 0 utf8length without calling reserveAndWriteUtf8
buf.writerIndex(startUtf8String); is moving the writerIndex with no clue that there are enough writable capacity to hold the short length prefix
replies.author: franz1981

timeline.author: njhill
njhill
njhill

timeline.bodyText: This is redundant for the same reason, but this whole method should only be used when it's already known that the buffer has sufficient space.. maybe rename it writeUTF8StringUnsafe or something
timeline.author: njhill

replies.bodyText:
this whole method should only be used when it's already known that the buffer has sufficient space

Agree as I've said on #10509 (comment):

I would like the whole required writable capacity to be already allocated and the assert should just check it.

So, how to do it?
As you've pointed on #10509 (comment)

it won't affect how the buffer is allocated

So, the only way to ensure there is enough writable space is to call ensureWritable just once, right after allocating the whole buffer? Or it isn't needed at all if the initialCapacity of the allocated buffer is enough?
replies.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText: I've changed it by assuming Or it isn't needed at all if the initialCapacity of the allocated buffer is enough? , please take a look and thanks for the detailed review Nick :)
replies.author: franz1981

timeline.bodyText: maxUtf8Bytes could be used to "ensure" space for these I think, filling in the length field retroactively
timeline.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: Let me rethink this part to handle this one as you suggest (currently  the writeUTF8String semantic while using the exact length is a bit different), because it makes sense
replies.author: franz1981

timeline.message:
Reduce garbage on MqttProperties

Motivation:

MqttProperties uses Integer keys instead of int

Modification:

MqttProperties uses a primitive key map

Result:
Less garbage produced on Mqtt

Reduce garbage on MQTT encoding

Motivation:

MqttEncoder create many byte[] to encode Strings into UTF-8 bytes

Modification:

ByteBufUtil::utf8Bytes and ByteBufUtil::reserveAndWriteUtf8 allows to perform the same operation GC-free

Result:
Less garbage produced on Mqtt encoding

Reduce garbage on MqttProperties

Motivation:

MqttProperties uses Integer keys instead of int

Modification:

MqttProperties uses a primitive key map

Result:
Less garbage produced on Mqtt

Reduce garbage on MqttProperties

Motivation:

MqttProperties uses Integer keys instead of int

Modification:

Result:
Less garbage produced on Mqtt

timeline.bodyText: Why not make it final and avoid further null checks?
timeline.author: paul-lysak

replies.bodyText: because IntObjectHashMap is different from HashMap: the former allocate upfront arrays internally, while the latter, nope. I've used null to save any allocation, if possible, similarly (or better) then what HashMap achieve internally. The JVM will null-check anyway a final field, so I've used a weakness of the JVM to our advantage
replies.author: franz1981

Result:

Reduce garbage on MQTT decodeMsbLsb

Motivation:

MqttDecoder was using a Result<Integer> on decodeMsbLsb

Modification:

Use some bit-tricks to pack 2 ints into a single primitive long
to store both result and  numberOfBytesConsumed

Result:
Zero garbage produced on MQTT decodeMsbLsb

Reduce garbage on MQTT decodeMsbLsb and decodeVariableByteInteger

Motivation:

MqttDecoder was using a Result<Integer> on decodeMsbLsb and decodeVariableByteInteger

Modification:

Use some bit-tricks to pack 2 ints into a single primitive long
to store both result ad  numberOfBytesConsumed

Result:
Zero garbage produced on MQTT decodeMsbLsb and decodeVariableByteInteger

Reduce garbage on MQTT Integer decoding

Motivation:

MqttDecoder was using a Result<Integer>

Modification:

Use some bit-tricks to pack 2 ints into a single primitive long
to store both result and numberOfBytesConsumed

Result:
Zero garbage produced while decoding Integers on MQTT

timeline.bodyText: seems that my codestyle IDEA Netty settings just apply to this forcibly
timeline.author: franz1981

timeline.message:
Reduce garbage on MQTT decoding

Motivation:

MqttDecoder was using unecessary Result<T>

Modification:

Use some bit-tricks to pack 2 ints into a single primitive long
to store both result and numberOfBytesConsumed and
use byte[].length to compute numberOfByteConsumed on fly.
These changes allowed to save creating Result<T>.

Result:
Zero additional garbage produced while decoding Integers and byte[] on MQTT
